content.title: Infrainguinal Vein Graft Surveillance
content.definition: Structured duplex ultrasound follow-up protocol for infrainguinal vein bypass grafts to detect stenoses before graft occlusion. Allows elective intervention to maintain patency, as occluded grafts have poor salvage rates compared to failing grafts.

key_concepts.description: Myointimal hyperplasia causes most vein graft failures at 1-24 months; stenoses progress to occlusion if untreated; failing grafts (stenotic) can be revised; occluded grafts often cannot be salvaged
Duplex ultrasound: post-op before discharge (baseline), 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, then every 6-12 months. More intensive in first 2 years (highest failure risk)
Peak systolic velocity (PSV) ratio >2:1 suggests 50% stenosis; PSV ratio >3.5:1 or PSV <45 cm/s suggests 70%+ stenosis or impending failure; low flow (<45 cm/s) predicts occlusion
Failing graft: stenotic but patent; 80-90% can be saved with intervention. Failed graft: occluded; only 20-30% can be salvaged with thrombolysis/thrombectomy
Stenosis >70% or low flow (<45 cm/s) or symptomatic stenosis â†’ intervention. Percutaneous angioplasty for focal lesions; surgical revision/patch angioplasty for complex stenoses
Surveillance is cost-effective because preventing occlusion saves limbs and avoids expensive secondary procedures; each prevented occlusion saves healthcare dollars
Early (<30 days): technical error, hypercoagulability; Intermediate (1-24 months): myointimal hyperplasia; Late (>24 months): progression of atherosclerosis in native vessels
After revision or angioplasty, restart surveillance protocol; these areas have higher re-stenosis risk
Always correlate with symptoms and pulse exam; some stenoses are hemodynamically insignificant; avoid unnecessary intervention
Less structured surveillance for prosthetic grafts; fewer interventions change outcomes; stenoses typically at anastomoses

learning_objectives: Understand the rationale for vein graft surveillance
Apply duplex velocity criteria for intervention threshold
Recognize that failing grafts have much better salvage than failed grafts
clinical_pearls: PSV ratio >3.5 or low flow <45 cm/s = high-risk stenosis
Most failures occur in first 2 years (myointimal hyperplasia)
Surveillance saves limbs by catching stenoses before occlusion
Once a graft occludes, it's very hard to save
Post-op baseline duplex establishes reference velocities
common_mistakes: Waiting for symptoms (occlusion may be first sign)
